items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: World renowned singer Napua Greig lives on Maui and says she's never seen a fire like this. "We don't know how the fire started, the rumour on the ground is it was a downed electric line," she told ABC News Breakfast. "We've had really high gusts of wind in Maui in the past day which has made it extremely difficult for firefighters to fight the fire." "But we have had a string of fires being set by people, so we don't know yet if the fires are caused by natural causes or if the fires are intentionally set." Greig says a lot of the island is without power and many of the spots the island is famous for are now gone. "If you're familiar with the area, a lot of the areas that are iconic are now gone," she says. "Front Street which is where a lot of our visitors like to go and shop and dine on the waterfront, is now gone. "And everyone goes to have their dinner cruises and enjoy whale watching tours, it's now gone. "The iconic tree that sits in the middle of the town is gone, a church that houses many of the leaders of theHawaiian kingdom is now gone. "A lot of historic sites are no more." US President Joe Biden has just ordered all federal assets on the island to help with the fire response.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Maui fire victim and singer Napua Greig says island has 'never seen so much destruction'

props.alt: A close up of a woman with long dark hair

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast )
World renowned singer Napua Greig lives on Maui and says she's never seen a fire like this.
"We don't know how the fire started, the rumour on the ground is it was a downed electric line," she told ABC News Breakfast.
"We've had really high gusts of wind in Maui in the past day which has made it extremely difficult for firefighters to fight the fire."
"But we have had a string of fires being set by people, so we don't know yet if the fires are caused by natural causes or if the fires are intentionally set."
Greig says a lot of the island is without power and many of the spots the island is famous for are now gone.
"If you're familiar with the area, a lot of the areas that are iconic are now gone," she says.
"Front Street which is where a lot of our visitors like to go and shop and dine on the waterfront, is now gone.
"And everyone goes to have their dinner cruises and enjoy whale watching tours, it's now gone.
"The iconic tree that sits in the middle of the town is gone, a church that houses many of the leaders of theHawaiian kingdom is now gone.
"A lot of historic sites are no more."
US President Joe Biden has just ordered all federal assets on the island to help with the fire response.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal Health Minister Mark Butler has told ABC News Breakfast the government has given up on support from the Coalition but is talking to the cross bench about getting on board with its cheaper medicines measure. "We had fruitful discussions with the cross bench and the time for a decision is this morning," he says. "I think we've made the case about why this is a very sound policy around the world. "Pretty much every country we compare ourselves to, they allow 60- or 90-day scripts for these ongoing health conditions. It is supported by every patient group I can think of and every doctor's group." Butler says he does not agree with the Coalition that it's been rushed. "I've read the motion that the Coalition is moving this morning and it doesn't seek to delay it by six months. The motion is to disallow the measure and it would go altogether," he says. He says he doesn't believe it will negatively impact the pharmacy sector. "I said first of all we would reinvest every single dollar the Commonwealth saves from this measure which is about $1.2 billion, every single dollar back into the pharmacy sector and we would talk to pharmacies and crossbenchers and others about the best way to invest that money."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Health Minister determined to get 60-day script plan through parliament

props.alt: Close up of Mark Butler on news breakfast

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)

Federal Health Minister Mark Butler has told ABC News Breakfast the government has given up on support from the Coalition but is talking to the cross bench about getting on board with its cheaper medicines measure.
"We had fruitful discussions with the cross bench and the time for a decision is this morning," he says.
"I think we've made the case about why this is a very sound policy around the world.

"Pretty much every country we compare ourselves to, they allow 60- or 90-day scripts for these ongoing health conditions. It is supported by every patient group I can think of and every doctor's group."
Butler says he does not agree with the Coalition that it's been rushed.
"I've read the motion that the Coalition is moving this morning and it doesn't seek to delay it by six months. The motion is to disallow the measure and it would go altogether," he says.
He says he doesn't believe it will negatively impact the pharmacy sector.

"I said first of all we would reinvest every single dollar the Commonwealth saves from this measure which is about $1.2 billion, every single dollar back into the pharmacy sector and we would talk to pharmacies and crossbenchers and others about the best way to invest that money."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government is rushing to save its plan to allow patients to buy two months' worth of medicine at pharmacies after the Opposition urged the Senate to tear it up. The move, which could see 6 million Australians able to collect two months' worth of medicine for the price of one, is set to take effect from September 1. Health Minister Mark Butler says it's one of the government's key cost-of-living measures. He said many Australians were having to make difficult choices between paying their rent, mortgages, putting food on the table and considering when they could afford the medication they need. The Pharmacy Guild, is heavily against the move with concerns it could mean community pharmacies go under. The Coalition says the government hasn't properly consulted the sector on the proposal. The opposition is set to move a disallowance motion in the Senate today, trying to use the upper house to block the proposal from occurring. This will happen unless the government agrees to renegotiate a funding agreement with the community pharmacy sector. ABC Political reporter Matt Doran told News Breakfast the debate would come down to the cross bench, after the Greens took Labor's side. This is the final day that such a parliamentary manoeuvre can be used before parliament breaks for three weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government set for Senate showdown on 60-day pharmacy scripts

props.alt: A close up of blister packs filled with tablets

buy two months' worth of medicine at pharmacies
after the Opposition urged the Senate to tear it up.

He said many Australians were having to make difficult choices between paying their rent, mortgages, putting food on the table and considering when they could afford the medication they need.
The Pharmacy Guild,
is heavily against the move
with concerns it could mean community pharmacies go under.
The Coalition says the government hasn't properly consulted the sector on the proposal.
The opposition is set to move a disallowance motion in the Senate today, trying to use the upper house to block the proposal from occurring.
This will happen unless the government agrees to renegotiate a funding agreement with the community pharmacy sector.
ABC Political reporter Matt Doran told News Breakfast the debate would come down to the cross bench, after the Greens took Labor's side.
This is the final day that such a parliamentary manoeuvre can be used before parliament breaks for three weeks.

items.synopsis: Just over a year out from the Paris Paralympic Games, Australia's Lauren Parker becomes a world champion in a second sport, striking hand-cycling gold after shining in the para-triathlon over recent years.

title.children: Aussie Parker wins world para-cycling title as Paralympics loom on the horizon

image.altText: A stylised graphic of the ASX board with an up arrow.

items.synopsis: Wall Street indices fall overnight but the Australian share market looks set to buck the trend and rise in early trade.

title.children: Wall Street falls, Australian market set to defy downward lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The big result out of the US overnight was Disney, which was a mixed bag. The bright spot was 13% revenue growth for its theme parks, products and experiences division. However, the company lamented some disappointing box office results for films including Elemental and the latest Indiana Jones adventure. It also reported another drop in subscriber numbers for Disney+ to 146.1 million, down 7.4%, mainly due to the loss of broadcasting rights for Indian Premier League cricket. The relevant Disney+ Hotstar product lost 24% of its users. Earnings per share was slightly higher on an adjusted basis, while revenue was a touch lower than typical forecasts. The broadcaster took $US2.65 billion in one-time write-downs and charges, which dragged it to a $US460 million net loss.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney loses subscribers after missing out on Indian cricket rights

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, I'm joining you for a short while to take you through a couple of the company results that Dan flagged earlier. First up, AGL. It might be hard to believe that an electricity and gas company could possibly lose money given current power bills, but that's exactly what AGL did last year. It's reported a $1, 264 million net statutory loss for financial year 2023, which just ended on June 30. How did it lose so much money? There's two main reasons: It wrote down the value of its coal power plants by $680 million after deciding to close some of them earlier than previously planned. It lost $890 million from the value of various financial instruments, mostly futures contracts for electricity, after government intervention and market forces caused the wholesale price of power to drop dramatically late last year. AGL was stuck with contracts that were above the new market pricing. Excluding those write-downs, AGL's underlying net profit after tax was $281 million, up 25%. And if you think that still sounds small in a sector where retail prices have just jumped by around 20-30%, then don't worry, AGL is about to make up for it. It has reiterated its forecasts for an underlying net profit of between $580 and $780 million for the current 2024 financial year. That is somewhere between double and nearly triple this year's profit. As a 'gentailer' — a power generator who also retails to customers — AGL is benefitting from "sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing" and expected improved power plant availability, with less forced outages. However, it says inflation, difficulty collecting debts of some customers and increased maintenance spend will cap profit growth. This blog covered AGL's June announcement about its updated profit forecasts, below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy company AGL posts $1.26 billion loss

featuredLink.title: AGL set to double profit as energy prices soar, ASX up, Wall Street rallies, Europe lifts rates — as it happened

And if you think that still sounds small in a sector where retail prices have just jumped by around 20-30%, then don't worry, AGL is about to make up for it.

As a 'gentailer' — a power generator who also retails to customers — AGL is benefitting from "sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing" and expected improved power plant availability, with less forced outages.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team here to kick off the day on our markets blog. The ASX 200 is set to lift (a little) despite losses on the key US indices. The Dow Jones was down -0.5% in trading, the broader S & P 500 -0.7% and the tech-focused Nasdaq -1.2%. The Sydney Futures Exchange sees the ASX 200 moderately higher when trading opens later this morning, up four points or +0.006% to 7,279 points. In March we found out that wages had lifted 3.7% in the year (well below inflation) through the Wage Price Index (WPI). That meant a cut to "real wages" — the income you have once you include what inflation has eroded from your purchasing power. There's new weekly payroll jobs figures out today, ahead of new WPI data on Tuesday. It'll give us a little look in to what's happening to pay packets …
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to rise despite Wall Street losses

children.content: Good morning,
Daniel Ziffer from the ABC business team here to kick off the day on our markets blog.
The ASX 200 is set to lift (a little) despite losses on the key US indices.
The Dow Jones was down -0.5% in trading, the broader S
P 500 -0.7% and the tech-focused Nasdaq -1.2%.
The Sydney Futures Exchange sees the ASX 200 moderately higher when trading opens later this morning, up four points or +0.006% to 7,279 points.
In March we found out that wages had lifted 3.7% in the year (well below inflation) through the Wage Price Index (WPI).
That meant a cut to "real wages" — the income you have once you include what inflation has eroded from your purchasing power.
There's new weekly payroll jobs figures out today, ahead of
new WPI data on Tuesday. It'll give us a little look in to what's happening to pay packets …
